Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The academics really is unbeatable. The school prides itself on its great facilities, professors, and curriculum
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: The academics really is unbeatable. The school prides itself on its great facilities, professors, and curriculum
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: The only required course at WashU is an introductory writing class (for Arts and Sciences).  That means that there is a lot of freedom in picking courses.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There is plenty of support to help students find research opportunities.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There are a ton of opportunities to get involved in positions on campus, most having to do with your major. Many professors have positions to offer if the student merely asks and shows interest in their work. The career center and advisers are very helpful in finding summer or winter break internships.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The CS professors aren't, on average, great.  The classes' structures are average.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The lecture classes are decent -- bad lectures are not prevalent and there are a number of good ones.  The smaller classes are great.  In both you recognize the intelligence of the professor and, in many cases, their genuine enthusiasm for teaching their subject.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: As I mentioned in my previous review, there are definitely some weaker classes/professors.  I'm not sure I'd say I'm enjoying myself in the classes, but I'm enjoying what I am learning.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Professors and classes in popular study areas are awesome, there are some limitations within the linguistics department, but the registration process is straightforward and the curriculum is varied and flexible.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: No major yet; no matter what it's intense
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Haven't had one but they are awesome!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Academics are phenomenal here at WashU!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Getting into my program was easy. The school does a lot to help you.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: For my specific program the unique part that I feel is that the companies that come to hire from the program are mostly consulting companies and since want to be in management consultancy industry this provides me a good match.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I am pre-med like most students here and it has been amazing!! Couldn't imagine being anywhere else!!
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Great school with amazing and caring professors that make learning fun and engaging.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Haven't had one but they are great!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: WashU is known for the sciences,
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's Washington University in St. Louis.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The academics are amazing and you will always have a professor teaching the classes.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I have not had one yet but I hear from my friends they are great!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: One of the best universities in the country so the academics are phenomenal.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Pre-Med/Biology is WashU's claim to fame in my honest opinion. It is one of the best in the country!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: IF you want to study it, there is a major for it. WashU is also very flexible in double majoring.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The connections WashU has with top employers is unbelievable. The numerous internships I've had in the medical field have been superb!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The academics at WashU are superb. The teachers add fun and an innovative approach to lessons which create an intellectual vibe here at WashU.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I am Pre-Med (as are most of my peers). WashU is known to be one of the best pre med schools in the country with a top medical school.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Amazing academics with phenomenal teachers willing to help you!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: WashU essentially feeds you internship opportunities. The school loves when its undergrads do research in any field.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Majors are very flexible when it comes to interdisciplinary study. You can easily double major.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Amazing academics coupled with amazing teachers!
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I am a bio major with a concentration in computational biology and I can tell you it is extremely fascinating! The teachers are great and always willing to work closely with you.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Top notch academics with a world renowned faculty! The amazing classes you will experience at WashU is overwhelming (in a good way)!
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I think we have a wild variety of courses offered to students. Although sometimes the very interesting courses are offered as much as they should be.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The process is very relaxed. The admissions requirements were reasonable. The interview process was very easy and inviting. Visiting campus was very welcoming and the community is the best. I recommend trying to stand out when applying.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The workload is rigorous in any part of the school. I enjoy it because I am pushed to my full potential. There are many opportunities for research and internships, and the school is willing to help you in any way.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics are rigorous, but rewarding. There are many opportunities for research, study abroad programs, internships, etc. The school wants to create extraordinary and intelligent individuals who will be successful in the real world.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: From what I have heard but have not personally had one
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am a biology major with a concentration in neuroscience on the pre-med track. Pre-med at WUSTL is one of the best in the country if not the best. It is what WashU is known for. Workload is tough, as it would be at any comparable institution.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Interdisciplinary studying is very common at WashU. The flexibility between the schools as well as programs is really unique to WashU. Many students will double major/ major and minor.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Internships aren't hard to find at WashU so long as you're willing to work and are relatively people savvy. Even if you aren't, there's something out there for you, and WashU is pretty good about connecting you so long as you know who to reach out to.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Honestly, there aren't too many jobs out there that can effectively utilize just a biology major. If you're not pre-professional, you can either go to grad school or be a lab tech. But on the flip side, Bio at WashU recognizes this and trains you not on content, but on thought processes applicable everywhere.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: WashU is rigorous. There's no doubt about it - it's a top tier school. But for the most part if you put the work in you can get results.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: It is very demanding and I am glad to be a part of this high academic program.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I love my major at my school. I think that it is demanding, yet satisfying.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I love the premed program. There are many advisors that help.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are a lot of options for people to major in.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Wash U is a highly ranked research institution.  Academics were challenging and flexible where students can take courses or major in crossover schools.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: So many people are biology majors.  Wash U is known for attracting a lot of pre-med students, many of whom choose biology as majors.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I'm currently a declared biomedical engineering major, though I have since decided to switch to applied math & biology this coming fall. It's to be expected--BME at Wash U, especially coupled with pre-med, is extremely tough. The introductory course for BME (BME 140) is everything like a "weed-out" class, and the professor makes little effort to encourage students in their feeble attempts to understand the course material, not to mention any remaining dreams about becoming an engineer. But although challenging, the school of engineering provides so many opportunities for research and internships that those who are genius enough to rise to the top can go far in the field of their choice.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: A portfolio was recommended for the architecture program but everyone who was accepted was flown out to the school for a personalized visit.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have yet to get an internship but the career office is readily available to everyone.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The internships I have had were over the summer and the university has a great program to give you scholarships since most internships are unpaid.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Lots of options for majors.  Lots of study groups available.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I work hard and am fairly challenged.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: WashU has a good mix of large and small classes. In my freshman year, I was in a over 100 people lecture hall and a six people seminar. The professor's are helpful as long as you reach out to them.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: To be a music major, there is no special process required. Majors are declared online with the click of the button. After that I just had to meet with my assigned music major advisor to make a plan for required courses. I am getting a Bachelor of Arts in Music but if you want a Bachelor of Music, you have to complete a comprehensive audition in front of the music faculty during your freshman or sophomore year.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The academics here are top notch. I majored in Environmental Studies and do wish that some things were done differently, that it was better organized, but overall I was very happy with the quality of instruction and fellow students.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I am very excited to have gotten in to the program, after all it is the 3rd ranked program in the nation. I applied here and only here because I have wanted to attend here ever since I was a sophomore in high school. I want to be a physical therapist and have no concerns about finding a job as last years placement rate was 100% if I am not mistaken.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: To get into the Physical Therapy Program at Washington University, you fill out the PTCAS application and it is screened and then sent to the University. The most important criteria were college transcripts, GRE scores, and experience. The biggest challenge I encountered was getting it in late. I still managed to get in, but was put on a waiting list. The application process was time consuming but well worth it. My advice is to APPLY EARLY!!!
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The sciences at Wash U is hard! I'm a premed student majoring in engineering. General courses (chem, physics, bio) are definitely hard and are considered "weed-out" courses. Engineering classes are smaller and still hard, but you can get help from many sources. It is possible to do well in them, but you definitely need to study and work hard!
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I've never been more challenged in my life. It can be a little overwhelming sometimes, but everything is manageable. Plus, there are so many available resources to help students.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I was able to be directly admitted into the business school when I applied for admission to the university. It was a very easy and stress free process.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I enjoy the program that I am in. Most of the classes are pretty interesting and some of them are difficult while others are not as difficult. The workload is as heavy as you want to make it. In order to get a really good grade, more work must be put in outside of class.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I am extremely satisfied with my program. The finance major focuses on all of the things that I am interested in learning and that will assist me in my future career. I hope to have a career in investment banking or private equity.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm a psychology major and I love it. It is really flexible and lets me explore areas that interest me. Additionally I can do research for credit, which is awesome. I've learned lots of interesting things and even got to go to a conference!
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Lots of close attention and faculty relationships in the social sciences and the business school, not so sure about the pre-med classes.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: My B.S. Applied Science degree is a non-professional degree, but it's good for students not pursuing an engineering career because the curriculum is very flexible.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I majored in Environmental Studies after taking several years to figure out my major. I enjoyed it, but since I was kind of late to get started, I felt a bit isolated in the senior seminar from some of the other students in the major who had been Environmental Studies majors all along. The major is different now at Wash U, but when I was a part of it, there were 3 tracks -- Biology, Ecology, and Social Science. I chose the Social Science track (less hard science) and was pretty happy with it. It was not a very tough major but it was intellectually stimulating. The three internships I have managed to get since graduating are definitely in line with the purpose of the major (to present environmental issues from a human and societal perspective).
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I chose this school because of the Archaeology program, and I am very satisfied with the experience I have gotten out of it. I was able to participate in two archaeological digs, which were invaluable in directing my interests post-undergrad. I plan to pursue a graduate program in Museum Studies and a career in a museum. Most of the jobs available to Archaeology majors right out of undergraduate are CRM positions, which do not appeal to me.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Classes taught by people either in the field or familar with it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: If you want a rigorous, academic environment with teachers who care and a flexible curriculum, WashU is the place to be. I have a class with four students and a class with two hundred, and everything in between. The workload can be intense but you can manage your schedule to make it fit whatever level you want.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I am in the Engineering School as a biomedical engineer, and I thoroughly appreciate the state-of-the-art equipment available to me, the vast research opportunities, and brilliant faculty in my field. The workload is tremendous, and the coursework is incredibly rigorous, both of which lead to a lot of stress, but I know that I will be very well-prepared for work in the field or for further study in a graduate program.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: A+ goes without saying. Almost every department here is fantastic. I think I'll comment on my schedule: There are a lot of early classes offered but if it pains you to wake up before 10 like it pains me, it shouldn't be too difficult to take later classes or a schedule that better fits your needs.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The overall academics are great! A lot is expected of you but it is definitely manageable.  The new curriculum is a little tricky but I am confident my core will be completed.  I unfortunately had a bad registration time for next semester so my schedule is not perfect but it shouldn't be too terrible.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Most of the teachers I've had were great.  However, this university has a very good reputation in many fields of research, and it is obvious that some professors, (especially in the science departments) are here for the research opportunity and not interested in teaching.  Dynamics are very casual in the architecture school- all professors are required to go by their first names and are very personable.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Being in the Olin business school has been a great experience. They really put a lot of effort into making it a truly special community. This includes great events, a lot of support and guidance. Students have a structured coure of study with a healthy dose of freedom.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Academics are very rigorous and challenging. That being said students have opportunities to take classes in many different areas and are encouraged to pursue their varying interests. Professors genuinely care about the success of their students. There are many resources to help students succeed outside of the classroom.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Great teachers, they are really interested in our success
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I love the courses, student life, and advising at Wash U. The Career Center helped me determine that my interests are best suited for the International Studies major and the advisors and support I have on campus have allowed me to succeed and become more of a leader.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Academics are great, of course, but it seems like there's a general feeling of inferiority from everyone that goes here--everyone thinks they're the stupidest person here. Classes here are a bitch, and don't expect to get all As.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Wustl is one of the top schools in the country. Biomedical Engineering is exceptionally strong.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Getting into the Arts and Sciences school is extremely easy if you have the credentials to get into WASHU i.e. a good GPA and a good SAT/ACT. The advising staff is great and finding what you want to do isn't really a problem.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Academic strength is mostly in the pre-med and business departments, but the school is expanding on other areas like engineering.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I loved my major of Health Care management- extremely rare and prepared me very well in an important part of the industry.  I also studied Spanish and my teachers on the whole were very high quality, and I liked the option of a pop culture class.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review:
I'm a systems engineer and I study computer science too.  Systems is good, the comp sci is alright. I've learned more in comp sci through personal projects and there is a small cult of really smart kids who do stuff like that sort of stuff.  I wouldn't recommend a math major here, I'd say the worst professors I've had here have all been in that department.

Arts & Sciences and the business school seem to be great. There are a ton of pre-meds and they seem to get into the best med programs in the country.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: International Area Studies – I love my major. The advisors are very knowledgable and the classes are great.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I'm applying to MD/PhD programs, so my summer research is my form of an internship. I have received great training and talk with my PI directly on a daily basis. Wash U is a premier research institution, and I benefit greatly from this as an undergrad.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Neuroscience Track of Biology Major Is Great! The courses are fascinating, the students are intelligent, and the professors are fantastic. I love my major.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Competitive Pre-Med, Uninterested Liberal Arts – very competitive pre-med classes. Liberal arts classes, there's not that much student participation in my experience. People study a lot, and teacher's do really care, and you can talk to them
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Premed Overwhelms the Campus – The academics are great, particularly pre-med. That can be good and bad though - it means that premeds are consistently stressed out, and non-premeds sometimes feel looked down upon for not being premed. That said, you cannot graduate without having received an excellent education.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: More Support Than You Can Possibly Use – The academics at Wash U are immensely challenging, although some majors are less intense than others. But no matter what your major is, the school never stops going the extra mile to ensure all possible additional assistance is ready at your fingertips. They'll pay group or private tutors for you, send tutors to your dorm some nights so you don't even need to leave your dorm building for help, they have tons of office hours (TA and professor), and so much more. Wash U has challenged me more than I ever though possible, and I'm now doing more than I ever knew I could, because while the school challenges me, it's there with me, simultaneously supporting me at every step along the way. That's truly exceptional.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Not gonna lie, Pre-Med is kinda hard. The work is doable so do not stress, just you have to be able to put in the time.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Challenging but Informative – Though most professors have high academic standards for their students, they do so because they want these students to succeed in their goals/careers. Help is offered in a number of different ways - learning centers, help desks, additional reading material- and seems to be available whenever/wherever you need it.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Everybody here is Pre-Med and wants to either do a Biology or Chemistry Major. It's very competitive.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Biology Major – It's easy to get a research position at the medical school. We even have an undergraduate research department to help you find a mentor.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The Olin Business School offers a practical curriculum complemented by talented professors. There are great networking opportunities and a number of corporations offer internships to Olin students.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The workload is pretty formidable but the professors are knowledgeable and the TAs and help sections are very helpful.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's a very challenging but also very rewarding experience. Without proper study skills it is difficult to succeed, but those can be learned from your friendly and helpful peers with ease. At WashU, academics are great.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Washington University professors and advisors definitely help you grow up because they hold you accountable for the quality of your work and your actions. They do not allow you to make excuses.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I'm in the business school, where Finance is one of the most popular, but also toughest majors. Typically the professors have top-notch graduate school degrees and/or impressive corporate experience in the finance sector. Finance classes require a significant deal of work and thinking.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Incredibly Knowledgeable Professors – I was amazed to find how interested and knowledgable the professors were. Sitting in their classes you can tell that they are really doing what they love.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Collaborative Academic Environment – I am about to declare my major in Philosophy-Neuroscience-Psychology with a focus in Linguistics because thus far, I have thoroughly enjoyed all of my classes pertaining to this major. What I find to be particularly interesting about this major and about the academics at Wash U is that the student body and faculty employ a very relaxed and collaborative method to teaching and learning academia. Even in upper level or curved classes, like many science courses, I find plenty of guidance and support from peers and educators whenever I need it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great Community – Washington University has a great community, and a very challenging workload. The community aspect really helps with the workload. I really love how all the people here are smart, and are able to ingage in intellignet conversation.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Biomedical Engineering – The workload is heavier than any other major here. The faculty is pretty sweet, but the BME class is ridiculous. The school has a weird sense of BMEs. If you really want to do BME, do it. Don't let the school or advisors tell you what to do.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics at Washington University in St. Louis are world class. Students have any amount of knowledge at their fingertips. The small professor-to-student ratio makes it easy to build relationships with professors. The workload is heavy, and the work is difficult, but this is all worth it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Good Help – Overall the business school is great. Interesting classes and easy to combine majors within and outside the business school. Great resources for finding internships/career opportunities.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: World Class Faculty That's Actually Approachable – Academics are one of the universities greatest strengths. Nobel Prize winning professors are numerous. Teachers want to get to know you. Classes are difficult but stimulating, and peers are engaged but not stuck-up.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: the curriculum offered at Washington Uniersity in St. Louis is outstanding.
Academics.Author: College Student

Academics.Review: Great Experience – Im in the College of Arts and Sciences and my experience so far has been phenomenal. The teachers are accessible and knowledgeable, and the students are clearly engaged.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The Good Classes Aren't Hard to Find – As with any school, some classes are great, some not so great. In my department, philosophy, any class at or above the 300 level is a good bet.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I actually started in Arts & Sciences and then moved into the Business School at the end of my sophomore year, when I finally figured out what I wanted to do.  I am now triple majoring in Finance, International Business and Spanish. I have also taken classes in the engineering school as well as University College.  WashU is great about taking classes in other schools. The academics here are very rigorous, and the library is always packed.  However, there are so many resources available that many people utilize like Cornerstone, the writing center, and school sponsored programs.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Mix of Large and Small Classes – I have had mostly great experiences during my time at Washington University with the academics. Typically, I have a mix of large lecture and small discussion classes, which is nice (especially on those days you're not in the mood to participate or be singled out). Some classes that should be small (around 20 students) get increased due to their popularity, however (to around 30+ students) which can make discussion difficult. I have been challenged by the academics here but have also found myself able to meet the challenge, which is fulfilling.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Washu does a great job ensuring that its campus is of great quality.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I was pleasantly surprised by the midwest. Coming from the Northeast, I didn't expect much but I love how friendly everyone is, and St. Louis is a happening city just as any other decently sized city is.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I come from NYC and I still love St. Louis. Obviously it has nowhere near the same quality or quantity of attractions, but Forest Park is beautiful and full of free awesome stuff, the mall covers most of my needs, the food you can find even within walking distance on the loop is amaze, and the local history and culture are super cool. A city doesn't need to be huge to be more than adequate. St. Louis does an excellent job providing for my needs.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: its BEAUTIFUL. We are consistently proven to have one of the best campuses in the world.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: The loop and clayton areas have so much to do and are pretty upscale. Forest park, which is right next to the school and is actually larger than central park is perfect for running and outdoor activities.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus is aesthetically absolutely stunning, to begin with. Looks gorgeous in all seasons. The athletic centers such as the South 40 Fitness center and the A/C are very well-equipped and accessible, with a new athletic center currently under construction. Dining halls (BD and the DUC) have a great variety of food and are comfortable to just hang out in as well. Olin Library is awesome for studying at any level of intensity and all of the staff is extremely helpful if you need them. Overall, quality of life on campus is fantastic.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: In a good neighborhood. But not far from more sketchy areas
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis has a lot of stuff going on and there is always public transportation to take you to local activities. Also, the happenings in Forest Park are often free and students can walk to those activities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: School is in a great suburb. some fun things to do
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Clayton, where WashU's undergraduate campus is located, is gorgeous. I've never felt unsafe here. Forest park has a ton of attractions, not to mention a great running space, and it's right across the street from WashU. The Delmar Loop is also nearby and provides quite a bit of shopping.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: ST. Louis has a lot of really cool things to offer for students and locals and tourists alike. I really like the fact that there is a metro system that has stops on campus, so we can get just about anywhere in the metro area without requiring a car. Locals are usually really nice to us, and there's a lot of stuff we can do in Forest Park that's free--museums, the zoo, walking trails. There's also an awesome outdoor ice skating rink open in the winter my friends and I liked to go to.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great music venues, parks, and everything is free- the zoo, museums, etc.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The campus is beautiful. It has plenty of green spaces and areas around campus for students to hang out.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Wash U has a lot of clubs that add to the community feel of the school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are two metro stops right on campus and since St. Louis is set up in an east-west line you can get essentially anywhere via metro. On top of that there's a carshare service on campus - $5 an hour to rent an enterprise car, located at every lot on campus. There's also a bus that shuttles around campus, circling around every 20 minutes.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The academic programs, social scene, facilities, campus life are really the best! Everything is always perfect and the students really love it here. Best quality of life.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Students are all very intelligent and enthusiastic. There are always events occurring on campus, and lots of free food!
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It's expensive if you want to park on campus. Your first ticket fine is waived by the school.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Thanks to the free metro/bus pass, I haven't had any problems getting places.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I have only completed one year at WashU so far but during that year the weather pretty much dictates your life. It was blistering hot last summer and I found myself always trying to stay cool. The winter was freezing cold and always raining and did not end until May. Which means we never got a spring. I hope next year is better.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is a HUGE park right off of campus that has a large amount of FREE activities that attract students (zoo, museums) as well as just a great place to study or exercise.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There a beautiful buildings on campus. The student union (DUC) is great because it allows study space, play space (game lounge), and eating all in the same location. It also houses student organization offices. Classrooms are generally spacious and desk are in good condition. There is an upcoming new recreation facility, as well as 2 recently completed business buildings.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking permits to park your car in a lot are pretty high but there is not much need for a car on campus unless you have a job off-campus. Even then, the metro can be pretty accommodating.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Many complain about the very unpredictable weather in St. Louis. There was a lot of snow and cold weather this winter, but that can be easily avoided with the campus bus and not long distances between lecture halls. Campus looks beautiful in any weather so the climate should not be a hindering factor for anyone looking at this university.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is a campus bus that circulates around campus on a daily schedule. It's location and pick up times are tracked on the free campus app so it is very easy to use. The school works with public transportation to provide free bus and metro passes to all students on a semester basis so it is free to get around the city as well. As a student, you can also register for free with Enterprise CarShare which allows students to rent a vehicle for a number of hours at a rate of $5 per hour if they need a personal vehicle to get somewhere (if it is to a community service project, the community service office will pay the rental fee).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You can take the subway (or a taxi) to Amtrak or the air port.  The main problem with transportation is that the subway system is fairly poor (to be fair, my only other significant experience with a subway system was in Berlin, whose system is fantastically convenient).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: "The Loop" is just off campus and is a great place to find something to eat, but apart from that we're fairly isolated.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: off campus trans is kind of confusing
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: experience all 4 seasons in a week. also allergies
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Internet is meh, lots of computers to use, though
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The circ is great, metrolink doesn't run super often, but it's not bad
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: St. Louis gets an undeserved bad rep, but there are plenty of fun things to do here
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I don't really know much about it because freshman can't have cars but I haven't needed one
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I went without a laptop for two months and didn't have a problem
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's usually great outside, especially now that it's spring.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The school pays for all of our bus and metro passes, so that's useful - it takes us straight to the airport and to most places around town. There are some times where we have to use an Enterprise Car Share program car to get places but WashU pays for the registration for that as well
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: NO snow days. Ever. Sun is out sometimes. Blinding
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Arch, City Museum, Forest Park, concerts, etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is sporadic. It can be nice. It can also be awful. It is like you wake up every morning and you roll the dice. The number you get corresponds to a weather condition. Its random so it doesnt matter what time of the year it is, you can roll any of the weather conditions.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: STL is a nice non-intimidating city
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You can rent cars from the university, use the metro, ride your bike, or use some combination of the three to get where you need to go in STL
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The wifi is improving, but it still is not as reliable as it should be on a college campus with a multi-billion dollar endowment.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Amazing facilities! The facilities look pristine and well-kept!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is VIBRANT! A ton of events going on around campus so that you will never get bored!!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is great at WashU!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Computers are fine in my opinion!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The local atmosphere is phenomenal!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Transportation is great here at WashU!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: This place gets all sorts of weather - rain to snow to sun to lots of wind. In the past week, we've gone from 20 degrees to 70 degrees back down to 20. St. Louis weather is pretty crazy, but you get used to it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis is a great place! Across from WashU, there is Forest Park which is full of fun museums and trails which are all free! St. Louis has all its attractions which you can access with the metro. There is the WashU bubble (where there is so much to do at WashU that people don't leave) but I would encourage you to get out an explore the area.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Campus transportation is free and using the metro is free since WashU gives you metrolink passes for free. If you want to go farther or elsewhere than the metro, there are wecars which are pretty cheap at only $5 an hour.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I'm not worried about needing a computer on campus. My main concern though is the wireless internet. While compared to places not fortunate enough to get wireless access, we are incredibly lucky, it's surprising how slow our internet is and how many problems there are for connecting to it. I guess I think for the amount we pay at Washu, we really should have much better wifi. Printing is great though in general I feel that WashU is oriented more towards macs so that there are more problems with PCs unfortunately.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The circulator is a good thing. Plus the bears credit helps you take discounts
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The university sends out updates when ever a snow storm hits to help students make alternative arrangements or when the campus is off because of bad weather. Also on campus transportation helps in making around no matter what the weather.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Student life is great on campus! We were voted one the happiest colleges in the nation.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The transportation is great due to the high level of taxis in St. Louis.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computers are great! The amount of technological resources we have is astounding.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather in my honest opinion is great because you get to experience all the seasons.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Loop is an area filled with restaurants and shops. It is an awesome place to hang out!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Amazing. One of the top in the country!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is very active on campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is fine. No problems with parking.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis offers a plethora of things to do!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather can be amazing at times!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers are phenomenal! I brought one to campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great and easy transportation around campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is extremely vibrant. Tons of happy and kind students around campus everyday!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are great and the university puts tons of effort into making them so awesome!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is fantastic! Never has been a problem.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Very easy access to St. Louis.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis really attracted me to come to WUSTL. The immediate town surrounding WashU is great!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers are great on campus!! You are allowed to bring your computer to class if you have one.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis weather is unpredictable. You get all types of midwestern weather but it is great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is amazing here at WashU. A big reason why I chose to attend WashU was because of its high quality of life. Compared to peer institutions, WashU students (according to numerous surveys such as the Princeton Review 2014) are the happiest and love their school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great facilities! Tons of resources too!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is not an issue here at Washington University in St. Louis.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers are great on campus. There is tons of help if you are having trouble with technology in general.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis is an amazing city with tons of great things to do!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You get the best of both worlds. If you like snow, you get snow. If you like scorching hot weather, you get scorching hot weather.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its really hot in the summer and extremely cold in the winter. Fall was amazing, but it lasted for about a week.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer labs are never full, and printing is free for the art school.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You definitely need to make more of an effort to go anywhere fun off campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking is fine in my opinion.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: WashU is a very vibrant community with an extremely diverse crowd! The facilities are beautiful and so are the people! Not only are the people brilliant, but they are also down-to-earth and willing to have a good time. Not once have I experienced a sense of cutthroat activity.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The facilities are amazing and very pretty! The school puts a lot of funding into the facilities to make them top notch.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Very easy to find great transportation in and around campus!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computer access is fine in my opinion. The internet connection is great!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: St. Louis tends to favor the extremes. It will be warm one day then cold the next. It's truly amazing and weird. The summer is EXTREMELY hot due to the humidity.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's St. Louis!! The amazing nightlife and opportunities make the city such a vibrant place to be!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: No complaints. I mean we get free passes for the public transportation.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Haven't really had time to explore, but there are things worth exploring.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Sometimes the internet connection really sucks. My roommate can't ever seem to get internet connection on her laptop in the library.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: In the spring and fall, the weather is great! In the winter, it can become very cold.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are multiple places to print and find computers. You are given free printing money for the year. The speed of the network is fast in the labs, but the wireless can sometimes act up in the dorms. There is no need to bring a printer, but a laptop is recommended.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is a campus shuttle that travels across campus everyday. Every student has a free metro pass to ride the buses or the Metrolink. Transportation is easily accessible and very convenient to get anywhere you want to go in St. Louis.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you want to explore St. Louis, you really need to have a car.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Weather favors the extremes in the midwest. It's either extremely hot or extremely cold, more so the latter.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: The metra is useful to get you to within 5 miles of where you need to go, but that's 5 miles of where you need to go. Bus lines exist, but can be hard to coordinate in a timely manner. Cars are useful, but enough things are accessible through walking, biking, or rental cars that you can get along fine without bringing your own.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is incredibly expensive whereas parking off campus, in locations totally inconvenient, is dirt cheap. If you pay for the on-campus parking though, it's pretty close to everything you need to get to.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: St Louis has some charm to it. But there's no doubt it feels like it's dying (to someone coming from Chicago at least). I wouldn't call it "City living at its finest", but I would call it an urban environment.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: WashU will put you against the anvil and mold you, maybe even break you in the process. That's part of what makes it unique. As hellish as those 4 (or more) years are, you can be confident that you are adequately prepared to take on the world. There isn't anything too special about it other than its grit, which is pretty special.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The architecture is gorgeous. The facilities are alright. Student life feels average. There aren't too many campus traditions, but the ones there are are pretty fun. It's a serious school.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: I think that the weather could be better but it isn't too bad.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are lots of computers on campus and many places to print.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is always something to do on campus and there is something for everyone.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I love our facilities. They are clean and open for everyone.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The city has much to offer but many students remain in what is known as the "Wash U Bubble," preferring to stay on campus or not to far from campus instead of exploring St. Louis.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: There is one computer lab for each residential college (a cluster of dorms) and the IT Help Desk was available for a wide range of hours (especially at night).
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: My home was several states away from school and the most convenient transportation was by plane.  St. Louis is a major city with an international airport so there was never any problem traveling between home and school.  A passenger bus was easily accessible between St. Louis and Chicago.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: I think many places seem to have sporadic weather and St. Louis is no different.  It's extra hot and sticky in the summer months and the proximity to the Great Lakes brought severely cold winds nearly every winter.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: If I were just to rate the computer labs, I'd say they're great. They're close where you need them, printing is cheap, and student tech helpers are always available. However, it's a good idea to have a laptop since it's still the more convenient choice. Network reliability and speed gets a low rating because wi-fi is scarce in most lecture halls. Even in my own dorm there are moments when my mac gets absolutely no coverage. But Wash U is working on it!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I've only gone off campus for one Target-run, a few celebratory dinners, and a ride to the top of the St. Louis Arch. There's not much to do off-campus that's interesting enough to leave campus. In addition, the city has a high crime rate and muggings aren't rare in and around campus. Wash U is known for having its small 'bubble' world for these very reasons.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus bus--called the 'Circulator'--circles the campus every 20 minutes or so and is especially helpful on cold winter nights coming back from the Olin library. Though to be honest, the campus is small enough where a 15 minute walk at most from one end to the other makes any form of transportation besides walking seem totally pointless. Students are given free passes to take the metro, and this is quite useful when making trips off campus. Usually trips off campus are for grocery/convenience store runs and/or off-campus eating but these are not really as necessary as they are purely fun.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: As mentioned previously, WashU offers all the resources you'd ever truly need. As a freshman I live on the 40, which is its own little living space with a student center, eating spot, convenience store, gym, dance studio, outdoor field, mail room… etc. etc. which makes even a typical ten-minute walk to class seem far. Wash U has stressed green-living so much that it's gotten a little overbearing as of late; landfill, compost, and recycle bins are everywhere on campus, and plastic Ice Mountain bottles are nonexistent.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I can't really compare WashU with other schools since I hadn't visited many campuses during the application process, but I can say that the resources provided for academic success are phenomenal. I often have a dilemma choosing whether to attend a TA help session, Cornerstone session, PLTL help, or the professor's office hours. The advisors, RAs, WUSAs, and other faculty members are always there to offer advice and support whether it's because I had a bad day or because I want to find a research opportunity. Speaking of research, as a research institution it's almost impossible to go for four years without a single research experience in lab. Lastly, WashU offers so many opportunities to get involved. Leadership positions are plentiful and informal clubs are a great way to launch that college debut.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is a huge parking garage right under the main campus that is big enough for most students with cars to park in.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The wireless internet is available in most places but sometimes will randomly go out for a few minutes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have no experience with the parking situation, but I have heard that parking is generally easy. The university police is strict about ticketing and fining if there is no permit. However, there is no need for a car on campus because there is a great public transportation system.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are many computer labs around campus and in the dorms. However, there is a cost for printing and it does add up quickly. In addition, the wireless network is not that great but the school is working on it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather changes a lot throughout the day and it is a four weather location with sun, wind, snow, and rain. However, it has not prevented me from experiencing college
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: WashU provides all students with a "free" (included in tuition) metro pass that allows students to ride the buses and metros unlimited, all semester.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: St. Louis weather can change literally overnight from 60 degrees to below 30. When it does snow (which isn't often) the university does a great job at keeping sidewalks clear and safe.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Students are expected to bring their own laptops (I don't know anyone without one). Again this perpetuates a culture of privilege within the university.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The permit costs are outrageous ($500+ per year). Not only does Washington University fail to admit students who are from lower socioeconomic statuses, but also make going to school there very difficult for those who do get in because of the huge extra costs of attendance - such as mandating freshman to live on campus in dorms that cost $14,000+ per year.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are many things to do very close to campus, including a free zoo, paddle-boating, biking paths, and an entire street dedicated to a variety of restaurants. Also accessible with free public transportation are multiple interactive museums, malls, and sports games.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lots of diverse options for everyone's interests
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything is very well kept.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: whenever I have a technology need, it is met.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: highly variable weather is exciting
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I haven't had any issues.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I am constantly in awe of how beautiful this school is!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Campus is right next to Forest Park which has a lot of activities accessible to students.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Students get a pass to use the public transit for free!  And the We Cars are so inexpensive, easy to reserve, and conveniently located around campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's a safe neighborhood located near Forest Park, which has several museums and outdoor activities that are mostly free. There are also lots of nearby restaurants and bars.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Since there are renovations, there are not as many spots available at this time.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Weather is seasonal. In the winter it is cold and snows. In the spring it rains. In the summer it is hot. And fall is really nice.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The computer labs in the occupational therapy program are available 24 hours a day 7 days a week.  They are fairly reliable and you can usually find a spot
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The weather is generally awesome. I'm from the north suburbs of Chicago and St. Louis is like chicago but milder. The fall/summer is VERY hot, but it's really nice otherwise. The winter is mild. It's great, honestly.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Easily accessible and convenient. The only complaint I have is that sometimes the logins are unavailable. It must be some kind of network problem, but I think they're fixing that currently.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computer labs are abundant, but they are somewhat dirty and sometimes the printers are faulty, however, they are fixed quickly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The computers are fine, but the frustrating thing to deal with is whether or not the printers will work. Technology at the school is very frustrating at times and our WIFI is still being figured out.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Fall is the most beautiful season! The colors are amazing. Summer is very hot and humid. Winter is very cold (especially if you are from the south) and this past year it lasted a very long time.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather is not really anything special. There are definitely enough days where you can stroll outside wearing just a shirt and shorts and be happy, but there are also way too many days from November-March where it gets cold, rainy, and snowy.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I guess the professor's research really sets it apart from other schools.  The teaching in classes sometimes suffers, but there are a lot of opportunities to do research in your field.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: For on-campus transportation, the campus circulator or "The Circ" is free and runs from early morning until late at night with convenient pickup times and locations. For off-campus transportation, there is one bus stop and two metro stations on campus and the school provides a free U-Pass for this transportation.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are pretty good, in that the DUC (Danforth University Center), Bears Den (dining hall), Olin Library (and the multiple other libraries on campus) are very well maintained and suitably provide for students. The green spaces on campus are beautifully maintained with blossoming trees and bushes as well, and overall I'd say you can always find a nice spot to sit and work quietly. However, my only concern is with the art school side of the campus, where facilities are very poorly maintained and the buildings themselves look dilapidated and worn out--I've spent many hours in these buildings and let me just say that the environment is not at all conducive to creative learning.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: WashU does an excellent job of providing students with resources--the career center is absolutely fantastic in that they have advisors for specific majors and career paths, colleagues who can help out with resume and cover-letter building, a website that can help you contact alumni in very distinguished positions in literally every field imaginable... In terms of research positions, as WashU is well-known for this, many of my friends (who are only freshmen) have already gotten positions in facilities at/through WashU. At this point, I haven't come across any door that hasn't been open for me...!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Wash U really likes to pamper its students, when it comes to facilities. All of the dorms are top-notch, even the oldest ones. The main Olin Library is also very nice, and students will often take naps in there because of the nice environment. Wash U's classroom buildings are also aesthetically pleasing from the outside and are as respectable as any other university's classroom buildings on the inside. The athletic center is old, small, full of concrete, and in need of an update, but sport is not really one of Wash U's main focuses, so many students will only go into the AC a few times in their time at Wash U. Green spaces are pretty good, with a nice Quad and open grass to play soccer and throw frisbees around in other parts of the campus. Hangouts such as Holmes Lounge are nice environments, even if they get overly busy sometimes. Campus activities are not too bad, though there aren't as many student groups as I would have liked and there wasn't as much diversity of them as I thought there could have been (too many a capella groups, for instance). W.I.L.D. is a nice campus event that brings some big-name musical acts to campus (free for all). There aren't all that many traditions at Wash U, though, and the ones that are there are newer than those at some other top universities. There also is no university press, which to me is something that every academically powerful university needs.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: When I was a student in the mid-to-late 2000s, it wasn't that easy to find a computer lab. The vast majority of public computers on campus were at the library. The library, depending on the time of day, could be crowded, leaving people waiting on computers. Printing was free and unlimited in my first few years at Wash U but had transitioned into a limited pay system by the time I was an upperclassman. One could still find a small handful of computer labs that offered free printing, however, like the Mac lab in the old Rubelmann dorm. Most dorms were not equipped with wi-fi when I started out as a student; ethernet was required. Classroom buildings and libraries had wi-fi, I believe, though it wasn't that easy to access. My guess is that wi-fi has expanded at Wash U since I left. I think almost all students had personal laptops but that most people would print using campus printers.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The computers are all very fast and new, with all the software you could every need, such as Microsoft Office, photoshop, etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The University provides a pass that makes all public transportation in the area free for students, and you can pretty much go wherever you wish as long as public transportation can take you there. Otherwise you can take taxis or rent campus owned cars for relatively cheap.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Transportation around campus is good: there is a circulator bus (which is often late but convenient) and wide paths for bikes. Public transportation is great for there are two Metrolink stations at opposite ends of the Danforth campus and a expansive bus system, both of which are usually on time.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: One of the great things about Wash U is how tightly-knit the campus is. The campus is small enough that you can barely walk across it without seeing someone you know, but it also has enough people that you can meet interesting people everyday. Midwesterners are typically very friendly, including the custodial staff and dining hall workers. Professors are also often very willing to spend time outside of class to meet with you.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The local weather changes often, so you really have to pay attention everyday. You will want a good pair of wellies, a good umbrella, and a warm jacket that is wind resistant. The campus is spread out, so you may be walking in exposed conditions.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You won't need a laptop during each class period, but you'll want your own to work on. Wifi friendly campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Sure it gets cold here, but the warm months are beautiful and even the snow can be pretty.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Plenty of computers in the library and in residential halls. Sometimes wireless access isn't ideal, but the tech support is great. You don' t need a printer, but I think it would be very difficult to get all my work done without the help of my computer.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Right near Del Mar Loop, one of America's top streets.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer labs are great! I can always find an open seat and they have macs.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Readily available and accessible for upperclassmen.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Expensive and the WUPD gives out lots of tickets for parking without permits
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Aside from the rigorous coursework found at WashU, many out of class research opportunities reside just a short metro-ride away on the Med Campus. Students often take advantage of the wide variety of research opportunities found both on and off campus. The social scene is great, there is a tight sense of community within residence halls and on the South 40 in general, and students are always friendly; many students find it common practice to study together on weeknights and weekends as well. Facilities are undeniably privileged and most are more than adequate.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: WashU makes a big deal out of making freshman feel welcome. Both the Student Union and the Congress of the South 40 (CS40), student government groups on campus, provide ample funding for the various programs hosted by a diverse range of student groups. Residential colleges promote college spirit and a sense of community through planned outings. With the Loop (Delmar Street) located just one block from campus, and easily accessible by a bridge overpass, students have easy access to off-campus stores and restaurants. On campus, the libraries are modern, the architecture is gorgeous, and there are always great places to hang out. The DUC is a common student haunt, one can find students there nearly all hours it is open: before classes, in between classes, and after class.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Anywhere you live/are on campus, you have quick and easy access to internet, computer chargers or a computer etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Coming from anywhere as cold as NY or Chicago, St. Louis weather is fantastic. We have some extra cold days but, for the most part, the average temperature here is just right for anyone who has a slight appreciation for winter.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I think the weather is really good. It isn't extremely hot at the beginning of the year and it doesn't get extremely cold either in the winter. It usually snows in Winter time but that doesn't affect classes or anything.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
St. Louis is a very likeable city, and Washington University's location is really awesome. It's true that it's not a major city and not as busy and vibrant as Chicago or New York for example but a lot of people love this relaxed atmosphere.
As for attractions, they are countless; like the loop and central west end. The city is filled with Museums, parks, and really good restaurants. And if you are a baseball fan, what is better than watching a Cardinals' game?
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It stays warm most of the year here, snowing 2-5 times in the winter.  Leaves are on the trees until mid-December, and then it warms up again by March or April.  It rains a lot in the fall and spring, and there are a lot of tornadoes in the fall.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Freshmen aren't allowed to have cars and as I understand it, the permits are extremely expensive with not a lot of areas to park in.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Missouri has great weather. It fluctuates a lot, and it's easier if you're from the north. A lot of my southern friends gripe about the cold a lot, but I personally think the weather is perfect. It's brisk in fall, mild in winter (though there is slush) and the only problem is that summers are really disgusting. But most students are off-campus during summer, anyways.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There is always someplace to go with something fun to do
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The main transportation is metrolink, which is basically one line that branches off at its midpoint.  It comes every 10-20 minutes and doesn't cover a great majority of the city, but does have stops at important city landmarks
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Gym is not state of the art and the cardio room was many times full, but it met my needs.  The campus is beautiful and the dorms in general are like hotels.  The library is big and helful with a great variety of study spaces.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
WIFI is available almost everywhere, but it's patchy and just not well put together.

Each college has its own computer labs with software specific for your degree, plus the Olin library has computers for general use.  Also each class is pretty well setup with computer, projectors, etc.

You can also get a lot of free or discounted software.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Spring and Fall here are incredible.  We get 4 seasons so there is a winter, but it is usually short and mild.  Also most of it passes over winter break so there is just enough to get a taste without it becoming depressing. It snows some and a few cold fronts move through, but it's over by mid February and it really starts to warm up.  March gets a lot of rain and storms but by April it's the best time of the year.  Summer is really hot and humid but I've never stayed for one.  When you return in the fall it's nice weather up until Thanksgiving.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Weather in St Louis is amazing! Always sunny and always warm.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Not Many Complaints. I'll be frank, I'm a Mac guy.  Windows and I just don't get along very well; I'm efficient and able to multitask....  BUT, the PCs here are very powerful and capable machines.  21" widescreen monitors are abundant everywhere.  Mostly Dell workstation systems in the business school and engineering school.  Residential halls have computer labs with 2-3 computers in them, usually all modern iMacs running both OS X and Windows.  Again, very fast, very capable machines.  Printing is all handles through a central print server and accounting system.  You are given a certain amount of $ per semester to print, depending on several factors.  

Internet is mixed.  Wireless has secure and non-secure channels.  Non-secure is easy to join and pretty zippy, but not secure.  Secure wireless is fast when its working properly, which is most of the time.  There are lots of issues with connecting and authentication because it uses WPA2 Enterprise and 802.1X.  Wired internet is just plain dirty (in a good way).  You'll see speeds around 85-95mbps download and 70-80mbps upload.  Just awesome.  Gaming isn't restricted at all.  Plenty of bandwidth, even on wireless.  I have gotten 80/60 on wireless several times, which is ridiculously fast.  All on-campus dorms have wifi.  Off-campus apartments owned by Wash U recently got free wireless as well.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Although the athletic center is nice it is too far.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Know Where to Go – The labs all have different atmospheres, and where you go determines whether or not you can get a computer during pretty much any time of the year. The ArtSci Computing Lab tends to have available computers, as does the Art and Architecture Library. Beware Olin Library. There are a lot of computers, but since everyone knows, everyone goes.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Everything Is Well Looked After – Everything is maintained and well looked after. The campus is clean.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: the perfect location – I love Saint Louis - it's welcoming, relaxed, historic, and beautiful. The immediate area surrounding WashU is comprised of Clayton (one of Saint Louis's best residential communities) on one side and University City (full of great apartments and endless places to eat and hang out) on the other. Plus, the Metrolink system makes it super easy to get around!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Immediate Off-Campus Area Fantastic – WashU could not be in a better location.  Located in a suburban area of the greater STL metropolis (that is very safe minus the occassional incident around the Loop), students are literally surrounded with numerous attractions.  Directly to the east of campus (as in all you need to do is cross the street) is Forest Park which is home to numerous free museums, a zoo, boating, ice skating, etc.  To the north of campus is the Delmar Loop which offers a wide variety of restaurants and the Pageant, which is popular for concerts.  The closest movie theater is a five minute drive and the Galleria mall (great shopping) is about a 10 minute drive.  St. Louis itself has so much small-city pride, especially for the Cardinals.  Downtown is vibrant with the arch, Bush Stadium, and Soulard.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
-Brand new fitness center on the South Forty
-Tons of libraries (including East Asian and Music libraries)
-New, popular student center (DUC)
-Lots of campus activities with free food :)
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Completely Unpredictable – The weather in St. Louis varies greatly day to day
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Olin Library Is Multi-Purpose – All types of studying are possible on 1 of 3 levels
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Didn't Snow Much – this year it was pretty nice - only snowed two times! In the spring, it would get rainy randomly, and it was often cold, but I never felt like I was really dealing with weather, except the one day it snowed I happened to be lugging a six foot piece of cardboard back to my dorm :(
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything Is New – The campus is beautiful. The collegiate gothic architecture theme is great and there's just one ugly building on campus (Eliot Hall) and they're knocking it down this summer and replacing it with a state-of-the-art facility to expand the business school. The South 40 has great facilities for the freshmen and sophomores - a fitness center with lots of cardio equipment, a dining area with a bunch of different cuisine options, and excellent dorms.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Friendly Atmosphere! WashU and the larger St. Louis community definitely have the Midwest Charm. Everyone at WashU, from the students to the professors from counselors to staff, is friendly and welcoming. The atmosphere at WashU is not cut-throat like other top-tier, largely pre-medical universities; students work and study together frequently. Students and faculty try to build a very inviting and collaborative atmosphere, which definitely helps with studying!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: WashU works very hard to provide clean and technologically advanced  facilities. The Athletic Complex and South Forty Gym offer several options for exercising often. The DUC (student center) is in a central location on campus and offers food options, seating venues, and meeting spaces. The libraries on campus offer great study areas as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: WashU students are eligible for the UPass, which offers free public transportation throughout St. Louis. Many students take advantage of the UPass by riding the buses and the Metrorail, both of which reach the vast majority of the areas of St. Louis that are visited by the students. WashU also offers the WeCar program, which allows students to rent cars for a specified number of hours at a reasonable cost. Lastly, many upperclassmen bring cars to campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Although the fall and spring in St. Louis feature picture-perfect weather, the weather in St. Louis tends to be variable and unpredictable. This past winter was considered mild, but it does snow. Classes are a 10-15 minute walk away from the dorm, so it can be rather annoying to venture to class when it has snowed. Students should also be prepared for possible tornadoes during the spring. Overall, though, the weather in St. Louis does not affect daily activity too much, and students always enjoy good weather during the spring and have fun making snowmen when it snows! The campus is also beautiful after a snowfall.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather changes constantly. One day everyone is bundled up in winter coats and the next the sun comes out and its really humid. You never really know what to expect. However, it seems to get warmer faster than a lot of other places which is something a lot students really enjoy.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
The library is pretty good, with plenty of study space and computers, and with a good location.  However, the book selection is surprisingly outdated.
The buildings are incredibly beautiful.
Student groups have access to countless facilities and resources. The athletic center is old, with a subpar gym area, many basketball courts, a pool, and many aerobics machines
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Widely Available, Except During Finals – There are computer labs in every residential college, in the library, DUC, business school, and several other places, so computer access is never a problem, except select times during finals.  I've never heard of anybody exceeding the limit on printing, after which you must pay per page.  The network reliability and speed is very high, except during finals.  The wireless network is pretty good too, although slower than the wired network, and is all over campus. Select outdoor areas even have wireless access, which is nice.
