It is possible to go through school without owning a laptop, but I would recommend getting one for convenience's sake.  Wash U provides software for both Windows and Mac.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The MetroLink is free for WashU students and takes you anywhere you would ever need to go in the Saint Louis-Clayton area.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: We have a good opportunity for jobs after graduation
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very Clean – the classrooms are all fairly new and well maintained.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Greek Life – We have great greek life. Sense of community everyone is really nice
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Relatively Reliable – Computers and printers are abundant and generally cooperative when you are trying to print 3 minutes before a paper is due
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The buildings, except for Eliot, are all beautiful. I think the only building that has to be redone is the Athletic Center. It is old and not even comparable to a lot of schools. The weight room is very small. Overall, however, the campus is gorgeous.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Finding your Niche – I think one of the best parts about Wash U is that everyone can find their niche. From bro'd out frat guys to the engineering nerds that only want to discuss the latest Python update to athletes to the laid-back eco-conscious awesome co-opers. Wash U is a great place for anyone to find a great friend group.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are definitely 4 seasons here. When you get here in August its hot and humid for a month then by october its 70-80 and pleasant most days. The fall colors are amazing and winter isn't bitterly cold at all like chicago, but still you will need a heavy coat/layers. The annoying part is that it doesnt snow as much as New York or Boston but it's just as cold. By the beginning of March it starts to get warmer again and by the time you leave in May it's pretty hot. Fall and spring are awesome but the weather changes very quickly, especially in spring. One day it's 70 and tornado watches and then within 24 hours it's like 35. No joke I went to bed one night when it was 70 degrees and woke up to 40 degree weather.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Best Around – The dining halls at Wash U are top quality. Bears Den and the DUC are really nice.  The Olin Library is always a great place to study and the AC is pretty nice too, although a little dated.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Public Transportation is great at Wash U.  All students can sign up for a free MetroLink pass to get them pretty much anywhere in the Saint Louis area, and there are busses that stop at Wash U for more local destinations.  You can also borrow cars if you need one
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Nice to Get Around – Some very good places to eat not far from campus. Grocery store, Walgreens and other useful stores are very close by in or near the loop. Forest Park is also nice to have.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: At least in my dorm only 2 of the four computers in the lab ever work.  The wifi is a joke and videos take an hour to load
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: So Much to Do That Nobody Does – St. Louis is a great city with so much to offer (especially free things) but I hardly know anyone who takes advantage of it. Since freshmen can't have cars, even though you're given a free UPass to use the metro, it is very difficult to go to the Soulard district, Tower Grove Park on Grand, Olive Street, Cherokee Street, etc. Also, there is always so much schoolwork and things happening around campus, many people never leave or experience much of St. Louis at all. However, I do feel very safe on campus, it's beautiful, the Loop is an awesome place to walk to for dinner and maybe a concert at the Pageant that always has great bands coming. Overall, I love St. Louis. I just wish there was easier access to off campus, community events.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: In Every Dorm – Labs in pretty much every dorm which is nice but the wifi is awful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are computers pretty much everywhere on campus, but a handful of places could use a few more. Printing is for the most part solid, but when there is the rare problem it causes a lot of trouble.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Do What You Want – WashU students work hard and play hard.  You can do whatever you want with as much or as little experience possible.  There are options for everyone to learn to do new things, and support for you to get help with career planning, academics, or social stuff.  You can do whatever you want and have people right behind you supporting you.  I know freshmen involved with research, I know art students studying abroad, and I know people who have started their own businesses.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Useful and Effective – If you don't have your own laptop, you're not really going to love using these.  The computers work great, and they are easy to get to/log on to, but they can't replace having your own computer.

I can print from my computer and pick it up on the way to class, or I can print from a computer lab computer.  The labs are never crowded, and I wouldn't suggest doing any projects on them; they might not be that trustworthy.

WiFi speed is pretty average, go for an ethernet cord.  If you are around campus, WiFi can get slow because so many people are on it, but it works fine.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Use the Upass – WashU gives each student and free UPass which allows them to travel on the MetroLink (kinda like a subway I guess) system for free. Don't be lazy, take the Metro to and from Lambert Airport. It's not a far walk at all and it will save you a ton of money, especially if you can't find anyone to split a cab with you. WashU is in a nice part of town, you will not be mugged on your way to the MetroLink station. That being said, the Metro is not good enough to get you to every part of the city. Taxis are needed especially if you are going to bars/clubs as a freshman (b/c frosh can't have their own car).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not a Necessity but Recommended – All libraries, dorm, and most lab buildings have some sort of computer lab. It is definitely not mandatory to bring a computer to WashU but I would highly recommend it. It is just so much easier to be able to carry around a computer with you then have to walk places to check email and stuff. The computers available to students vary but they are all relatively modern in design and are easy to use.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Windy in Winter – During the winter, it can get really windy and that is the worst while walking between classes or to/from the dorms.  Underclassmen usually live about 10-15 minutes away from classes and so that walk can be brutal in the wind.  However, in the fall and spring, it is GORGEOUS and it is hard to make people stay inside.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The WiFi is not good--until I got an ethernet cord, it was impossible for me to steam any videos online. After getting the ethernet cord, the internet is usable; not extremely fast, but I can always stream videos. There is a computer lab and printer in every dorm, which is pretty reliable; there are almost always computers open and I haven't had an issue with printing. Student Tech Support is really great, very reliable, quick to fix almost any problem.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Options, Options, Options! At Wash U, you can seriously do anything. You can be involved in faculty research as a freshman, jump right in to you major classes in your first semester, join and be able to actively participate in 3 different student groups...
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Open Doors – This school really makes an effort to connect you with the resources you need to have a successful future. It is really easy to find an internship or research assistant position in a field of your interest during your studies here.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Everything Good but AC – The facilities here are excellent. Wash U builds new buildings unbelievably quickly, and renovates others. The athletic complex is rather lacking (the weight room is often packed to capacity) and is not up to par with the rest of the school. As a Division III school, this kind of thing is never on top of the priorities. However, many buildings have been built in the last few years, including the engineering facilities, and they include many new technologies and are in general quite nice.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Arch – Visit the Arch! Also, St. Louis has the largest free zoo inside Forest Park, a great place to go on an afternoon walk.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: St. Louis – The Loop is right next to campus, offering restaurants, bars, and entertainment. St. Louis is the home of the Cardinals and the Blues, and is also home to many ethnic restaurants. There's a mall accessible by the public light rail system.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I feel very confident in my ability to get a job after graduating. The career center is incredibly helpful. It fully prepares students for interviews and helps them on their job search. The alumni network is also very widespread and supportive.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It is very easy to find research opportunities on campus if you just approach professors. WashU is a very research-heavy school, and encourages students to find internships and research opportunities.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There is a career center that helps with internships and job opportunities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The career center is very helpful.  They helped me put a resume together and directed me towards a summer internship program.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Having the name of WashU behind you really helps when looking for a job. But jobs are still hard to come by.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I wouldn't have come to this school had I not been so impressed by the job opportunities. 80% of those that apply to post graduate programs get in.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I believe that Wash U offers students the opportunity to get a top tier job right after graduation.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Wash U is highly regarded among employers.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Tons of career center services exist in place to help you get a job, not only right after graduation, but also for the next few years of your life. Pre-professional advising tends to be very good and students often end up wherever they want, as long as they do well in the necessary classes. If you do well here, you earn any job you want.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: This school has an extensive alumni network and looks amazing on job applications. It also looks really good for graduate/medical/law school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Good internship opportunities, and help from the career centers. Especially considering subpar location.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Although the name isn't recognizable as Harvard or Yale, the professional world is still very aware of Wash U. The career center is known to be helpful even after you've graduated when it comes to finding a job or graduate programs.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: As a member of the Olin Business School, there are many opportunities for business school students. The career center is very helpful and there is nearly a 100% job placement rate after graduation.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I've heard that students from WUSTL tend to look better compared to applicants from other schools because of the academic rigor and how prepared they seem.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Whenever I tell people I'm studying at WashU, they immediately look at me with more respect. I'd say the value of a degree here is much higher and of a degree at another state school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: School and fellow students are good connections.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: A Wash U degree is pretty relevant and taken with extreme consideration from what I've heard.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have yet to explore that yet
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The career center is great. They got me a great internship this summer, and all of the upperclassmen I talk to say great things.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I didn't get as much aid as I needed and we had to contact them to negotiate. I could still use more aid but they're not willing to help too much.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Getting financial aid at WashU isn't the problem--getting in is. That said, sometimes the Financial Aid counselors can overlook your email, but they're generally really helpful.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The alumni network is strong coming from a midsized school like WashU with a strong sense of identity and a satisfied student body. National reputation is on the rise, getting better every year, and employers know a degree from WashU is the best.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid probably happens, but the socioeconomic status here is unfortunately quite homogenous.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: people from washu make a lot of money
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It was alright. Interviews can be extremely stressful, but doing your reserch on many different types of schools will help you be satisfied with your choice
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Everyone I know has gotten what they want
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Yes Wash U is expensive. However, I found it quite easy to get aid. I just sorta asked and gave them my situation.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was only able to receive a small scholarship after lots of back and forth on my parents' and the financial services representatives' end. The scholarship applications for incoming freshmen should be taken seriously and students should allow ample time to complete them as they require teacher recommendations. I mistakenly did not have completed the entire teacher recommendation section of my applications and I believe that if I had given myself more time to organize them it would have greatly benefitted my chances of receiving more scholarship money.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Lots of scholarship opportunities, generous with financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: This school is highly and nationally regarded.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid office is very accessible and will listen to any financial concerns you may have.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was fortunate to receive a full tuition scholarship to school, but now I am still struggling with paying for housing and my meal plan. So far, it seems to be best to make appointments with financial aid counselors and talk to them face to face.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The scholarship was able to cover almost all the cost of school for 4 years
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Extraordinarily generous.  Ask and you shall receive.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Good financial aid. Few scholarships that are really hard to get but v. generous
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Scholarships are awesome at WashU. We are rated #6 in terms of National Merit Scholars.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: WashU offers great financial aid and merit aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: WUSTL is rated #4 in giving out financial aid/scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: WUSTL offers great aid and merit scholarships!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: WashU is one of the few top schools that offers merit scholarships.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Great Financial aid. Probably one of the best! When comparing the schools I got into, WashU gave me the best!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Wondering if scholarships are available to 2nd and 3rd year students
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: From what I hear, WUSTL offers great financial aid to those who need it. WUSTL also gives huge academic scholarships to its merit scholars (which there are a ton of).
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: While I did apply for aid, based on my family's income and the lack of aid I had received at other schools, I knew I would not get any. However, each student is assigned a financial aid officer with whom they can meet at anytime throughout the year, with or without an appointment.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I had a decent experience with financial aid and know other who also did, but the number of students on financial is substantially lower than those paying the full sticker price to attend.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: WashU has many full and partial tuition scholarships, and always meets students' full financial need (oftentimes giving students more aid than their government-specified need).
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid process at Wash U is the easiest of all the schools I applied to. With other schools you have fill out tons of paperwork to appeal your financial aid decision, but at Wash U you're given a financial aid counselor and you just email him/her. My mom emailed my financial aid counselor on Friday and she got back to us on Monday with a new figure for the amount of financial aid I would be receiving. Wash U always says that once they've accepted you, they'll do anything they can to help you attend - and that's true.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They have several scholarships, but in a limited quantity.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Scholarship Groups – Scholarships are weird at Wash U. I don't know if there's THAT much financial aid, but there are a lot of people on really big academic scholarships, and they all come in March when they're accepted, they're flown in for free, and then all the scholarships have names and all the kids in the scholarship groups become friends. The financial aid might be good though.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: This school hooked me up with a decent financial aid package.  I mean its ridiculously expensive to go here so anything from 20000 and up off is necessary.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Getting financial aid at Washington University is extremely easy. Everyone is helpful in the financial aid office. The best bet to receive financial aid is to apply for it early and be vocal about needing money for school.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Not Need Blind – The school itself is not need blind so if you can pay the tuition costs you are probably slightly favored. Financial aid however, for those who receive it is great and fairly easy to get.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Great Scholarship Program – I did receive a scholarship that paid for most of my costs. The program is great and there are a lot like it associated with the university.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The people working in the financial aid office are very nice and friendly. However, the price of tuition, room and board, etc. is so high, the money from financial aid doesn't help all that much.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The only reason I'm at this place is because I was given a full scholarship
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Washington University really goes above and beyond to help their students afford college. They were cognizant of my finical position and they really helped out. My financial aid package helped me go to one of the greatest schools in the nation.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Scholarship Programs – There are a few great merit based scholarship programs at Wash U. This includes Rodriquez, Ervin, and Danforth scholarships. These scholarships also foster a community within its recipients
Value.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food is delicious. Great variety and great quality food. When ever I visit high school friends at their colleges I realize how truly incredible WashU has it with food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We rarely have to venture off campus because on campus food is so good, but it's also hard not to because of how many great options there are close by whether it be on the loop or in the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is fine, but somewhat inconvenient since it usually involves planning an entire outing.  Off-campus dining usually means paying with your own money instead of meal points which can be annoying as well.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The food on campus is amazing. There are so many great options and it is possible to never have the same meal twice.  My favorite are the stations that constantly change the meals, like WorldFusion and Comfort Meal.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Ranoush and three Kings Pub are both amazing for a nice night out.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I can always find something good to eat, the problem is that I have to buy more meal points than I actually used.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are some local restaurants that are cute and really close- right on the loop. Otherwise St. louis has really good food also! If you go into the city you'll easily be able to find somewhere great.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's such a huge variety you can find anything for any mood your in. Down side is that Paws n Go has some really expensive stuff.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Loop is easy to get to, and the food there is all reasonably priced and good. I especially recommend Blueberry Hill or Fitz's if you're looking for good American food. For less traditional tastes, Seoul Taco is always great. Oh, and Piccione Pastry always has something delicious and sweet.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: WashU has some really great food, but you have to wait for it. Pretty much everything you get that isn't prepackaged can be custom-made for you. This is great because you get to choose exactly what you want, but this isn't so great because it can take a while to get your food. Also, they charge you for things like extra veggies or extra meat, which can add up if you get it every day.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great ethnic food in the Central West End (?) esp. Ethiopian, vegetarian, and Asian. The Loop next to campus also has some great options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Tastes great for a while, but (as always) can get boring.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great food on the loop.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Too many health conscious options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I wish there were the same meal options that there are in the law cafe in BD.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: St. Louis may not be the biggest city but it's definitely a city and there are a ton of delicious varied off campus dining options. The loop is great and has a lot of student discounts available as well, and if you were to venture further into the city you would find an even greater variety of interesting and high quality food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a ton of dining options on campus that take meal points and/or bear bucks, and the food is delicious.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: probably some of the best options for a college
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The campus food is delicious; there is a lot of variety. BD serves good food, but some special places include the Law Cafe and Holmes Lounge. I'm also a fan of Stanley's, in the basement of Lopata Hall.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Less than a mile off campus, there is a street called the Delmar Loop full of restaurants. There are some chains, such as Chipotle, Starbucks, and Noodles & Co. There is an amazing bbq restaurant that is a little nicer; there are endless ethnic restaurants, a great burger/rootbeer restaurant, a mac n cheese restaurant, several sandwich shops too.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the restaurants around campus. Some favorites are Pastaria and Seoul Taco. Its so fun to go out to eat with friends on a weekday night after class or on weekends.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The Loop is always a good location to go if you are looking for Off-Campus Dining.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: St. Louis has some of my favorite restaurants. I love Ibby's on wash u's campus but also love getting some work done at a local gourmet coffee shop called colleens cookies. For brunch it's hard to beat Half & Half but I also love First Watch and Roosters. For dinner there are hundreds of options. All around Wash U's campus are stores with student discounts and the ability to use the Wash U card (which mean's no tax). Most restaurants are a car ride away, especially in the winer.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The Loop is a great place to go for off-campus dining. There's a great variety of restaurants to choose from and many accept the university's "Bear Bucks" system. Easy to get to and a wide spectrum of costs to suit whatever you're looking for.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The loop has a pretty good variety of options but that can grow stale pretty quickly. Other options are not too far away by metro or by car
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The Loop right off campus has a ton of good choices catering to a variety of price ranges!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We have a street called the loop 10 minutes from the school that has some nice restaurants. At this school, the regular dining food is so good and the off campus dining is so far away that there isn't much reason to go there on a normal day.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Our campus dining is fantastic! We can get food on some places on campus up to 1am most nights, they have excellent dining staff who always talk to us and are really nice, the meals are really tasty and are usually pretty healthy, depending on what you get. BD and the Village House are the best places to get good food--the Village has the best brunch options on the weekends, both are open late, and both have the best staff. You can find just about everything on campus, and if it's not there, then its nearby and takes BearBucks.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Lots of good places to eat on the Loop or in the Central West End.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Wash U accommodates all dietary needs including Kosher, gluten free, vegan, vegetarian, and allergies. They have tons of different stations and food varieties in the DUC and Bears Den, and it changes every day. It's very easy to eat healthy, whether thats getting salmon or another lean protein from the grill, getting veggies steamed for you, a veggie omelette in the morning, or fresh fruit, berries, and a salad bar in the bear necessities shop just kiddy cornered from Bears Den.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The central west end is full of great restaurants to try but you can venture out a little bit further and find some fantastic food on the Hill (best Italian food), downtown on Wash Ave (great bar food).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is a street about 10 minute walk from campus that is rated one of the top streets in the nation for its variety of food and shops. The eateries are all unique and provide many options for off-campus eating that allow for delicious variety. Most of the establishments also either take the campus card or provide a student discount so it is very amenable to students.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: there's a wide variety and it's all pretty good
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The Loop has great food!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We live right next to one of the best food streets in america so that doesn't hurt
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off campus dining is fabulous!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is so much great food so close to campus. A+
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus dining is awesome! Rated on of the highest in the country!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food at WashU is stellar. There are all sorts of different places to eat and if you get tired of one place, there is no need to worry. There is also a delicious fancy restaurant called Ibby's which you can use your meal plan at. Overall, the food has a lot going for it!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I don't go out often, yet when I do, I enjoy the time I'm out. Off-campus food is on the loop which is a little bit of a walk but once you get there, the food is delicious and there are a lot of choices.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Need to find more places which offer kosher or halal food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Wide selection of tasty food!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's phenomenal! St. Louis has food to die for!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus dining is amazing at WashU!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's St. Louis. It's great!!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Campus dining is great and is constantly ranked among the top in the country.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: St. Louis has amazing food and dining options!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Campus dining is amazing. Period.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Washington University in St. Louis is known for its food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Endless selection of amazing food!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Pretty great actually. The food in St. Louis is incredible!!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I've only been out a few times, but I hear really good things.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Loop is very close to campus. There is a lighted pathway to walk there and it is very safe. There are plenty of options and varieties of restaurants. Many of the restaurants have will use your campus card Bear Bucks.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is phenomenal. The Loop, which has been called the Broadway of St Louis, is within a mile of main campus and offers an incredible selection of one-of-a-kind dining options, and a few familiar necessities like Chipotle and Noodles. Delivery services are also alright, but not necessarily note-worthy.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The food is good - no denying that; but, everyone always adjusts. It can be a little pricey though. But the great thing about WashU is the fact that the Loop offers a huge variety of dining options should one ever get bored.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: We have one of the top ratings for food in the country and I love it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The Loop is close to campus and has a variety of restaurants, some known chains and others unique to St. Louis.  Students can use Bear Bucks (money loaded into student accounts and used through ID cards) at off-campus dining locations.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I liked that there wasn't a stereotypical, gross "cafeteria" but several eateries across campus including a Subway and Einstein's Bagels.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Wash U's food is nationally ranked so it deserves nothing less of 5 stars here. If you don't mind the walking, there's always someplace new on campus to keep things interesting. Ethnic cuisine is easy to choose from, and if convenience is your thing, Paws & Go is a quick way to grab food from a convenience store. The latest you can grab food is 2 AM. There's really nothing more that can be said about dining aside from the fact that meal point plans are a tad expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most students dine on 'the loop' when off-campus. The restaurants there include all sorts of Thai, Chinese, Japanese, Mexican, American cuisine. There's definitely enough variety to keep the interest high, although there's only a handful that provide truly 'worthwhile' food. Cost can be at both ends of the spectrum. There are no student discounts offered, although some accept 'bear bucks' which can be added to the student's campus ID card.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food and eatery quality is really high, though costly.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: While dining off campus is a little ways away from the dorms, there is a wide variety of food places. Some of these include local restaurants, like a great thai place, or chains such as chipotle or noodles and company. Also, St. Louis is the home town of Panera Bread so that is an option as well. There are very few discounts for students but the food is not very expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are multiple dining halls, each with a large variety of food options. Many meals are made to the order of the students, allowing everyone to personalize their food. The food is bought off of the dining dollars, called bear bucks. My favorite place to eat is the stir fry of bears den.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: St Louis has a GREAT variety of foods. But you really need a car to get to most places.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There is always a good variety of food to eat, with a kosher station as well as vegetarian and vegan options readily available as well as clearly labeled. Multiple dining locations make it convenient to get food. Although at peak times there can be slightly long lines.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Campus dining is amazing!  I have a food allergy, and they do a great job of accommodating me so that I can eat safely, and have options that I like!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Lots of great options within walking distance of campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The campus dining options here are gourmet -- you absolutely cuold not ask for anything better. I'm a vegetarian and I had a myriad of options to choose from. Healthy and good -- but pricey.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There aren't a lot of places, but the places are amazing. The food is UNREAL. It's a little expensive, though. The food is just so good.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Amazing... Here you can find almost anything anytime. There's a new pilot program that I helped test out that even delivers food to your dorm. There's so many places on campus that are great for grabbing food (if you don't want to stand in line) such as Stanley's, and then there's the amazing Holmes Lounge (that has the best wraps), conveniently next to the library.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's okay. There's a number of good restaurants around.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is an area about 10 minutes from campus (walking) called the "Delmar Loop". It was recently rated one of the top ten streets in America and has lots of local restaurants as well as some chains restaurants and ethnic cuisine. I recommend Pi pizzeria, which is so good that president Obama had their pizza flown to the white house.   If you are looking for a more variety in ethnic food head down to the central west end (10 minute by the metro) to sample a wider variety. If your looking for something classy head to Clayton(5 minutes by car). There are also lots of places in the area that deliver.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: WashU is the best school for food. Prices are pretty expensive, but there is a lot of variety in terms of cuisines and healthy options. 2 dining areas (Bear's Den & Village House) by the dorms are open really late into the night, so students can always grab some food in the middle of their late night studying. Everything is based on a meal point plan that decreases in amount by the price of the food. WashU's dining isn't buffet/swipe style like most other colleges. Instead, you pick whatever food you want off a menu and pay for it on your way out.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I honestly can't complain about Wash U's food because it is the best food I've had on any campus.  I wish some places stayed open later (URSA'S), but there are so many choices for food and there are many that aren't listed on the menu.  Cafe's are found around campus in case you're in need of a quick pick-me-up which is really convenient, but just know when to go so that you won't get caught by a huge line.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You could starve to death on this campus. The food places are well hidden.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: St. Louis Dining has a variety of types of food, all with good to great quality; the difficulty is that not all of the best resturaunts, are centrally located.  Several are spread out all across the city/county/region.  If you are looking for something specific, you may have some distance to go before you find it.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There's an area called the Loop a very short distance from campus which has a huge variety of places to eat. There are your normal restaurants, like Chipotle and St. Louis Bread Co. (Panera), but there are also a bunch of Thai restaurants, a restaurant that sells only mac n cheese, and bigger places like Fitz's and Blueberry Hill. Kayak's is also very close to campus - it has good coffee and even better Belgian waffles.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great food and great staff. Every Friday night I would go and get chicken and waffles from the Village and Charles knew to expect me and would have my order ready before I got there so I did not have to wait for my food. Always got the best food on campus.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The food is great and there are different options across the campus. The carvery wraps are fantastic!
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: The food is great and there is a great variety of options.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great Restaurants on the loop right off campus. More great restaurants spread around the St. Louis area, but not as well known.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: St. Louis has great food. And its just a short walk or metro ride away.  The Loop has plenty of options for when students need a break from the usual campus food.  Blueberry Hill on the Loop has a killer burger and Pi Pizza is a popular pick.  The Loop also had chains such as Chipotle adn St. Louis Bread Co.(Panera). Students do venture to areas such as Clayton and the Central West End but the Loop is the easiest and most accessible.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Wash U wasn't ranked as high as it is in dining for nothing.  With various cafes, a fine dining restaurant, and the usual campus cafeteria, Wash U has all bases covered.  And the food is GOOD! Bears Den, the main dining hall for freshmen and sophomores has an absurd amount of options.  However, its easy to get bored with it if you don't branch out.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food is great but overpriced. The lack of healthier options is annoying sometimes, and despite the wide array of options, eating on campus does get old after a few months.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is extremely good. There are lots of options. Meal points should last you the entire year and it's not a huge deal if you get behind at a certain point. All the food is very good.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Options Galore – Tons of options at the DUC.  Einsteins and subway are always near by.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Good Variety Overall. On-campus food is preposterously expensive, so it's nice to have some good off-campus options.  In a one mile radius, there's Einstein Bagels (apart from the one on campus), Boston Market, Schnucks (a supermarket that is 24 hrs and has tons of everything), a couple of one-off, awesome sandwich and cheesecake places, Domino's Pizza, Jimmy John's and the rest of the Loop, which has Fitz's, Blueberry Hill (I got bad service here), and Wong's Wok, which is pretty much the best Chinese food around.  Pretty cheap, as well.  But they only take cash.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Hit up the Loop – The Loop, Delmar Boulevard from about Kingsland to Des Peres, is a wonderful street full of dining and shops, as well as entertainment venues. The dining options range from chains like Panera/St. Louis Bread Co., to local restaurants like Fitz's. With a variety of ethnic food restaurants (from Chinese, to Thai, to Middle Eastern, including kosher options), as well as American food staples, the Loop has dining for everyone. Located a ten to fifteen minute walk from main campus, the Loop is easy to get to. There are discounts at some stores, and more shops are beginning to accept "Bear Bucks", which students can load onto their ID cards from their student accounts to make paying for laundry, school supplies, etc. easier. Definitely check out Fitz's for the root-beer floats (they make their own root-beer) and make sure you hit at least one of the Thai food restaurants.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Good but Repetitive – It's hard to not be repetitive but the food is generally good with lots of vegetarian options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Delicious but Can Be Pricey – The restaurants surrounding Wash U. are almost all (at least the ones I've been to) very good, but unfortunately can tend to be on the more expensive side, which is difficult for us poor college students. However, usually the yummy food makes up for the fact that you will be continually broke if you go out to eat.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Too Good to Be College – The food at Wash U is AMAZING! I have two siblings attending other colleges, and I'm always stunned by how good Wash U's food is by comparison. Everything is extremely fresh, nearly everything is made-to-order, all food is locally sourced and sustainably produced and prepared. For any given dinner you could choose from Mexican food, Indian, Italian, Mongolian stir-fry, grill, or comfort food. They have great healthy options and the chefs are all so nice about customizing your meal. I am very conscious of eating healthily, and the chefs are always great about preparing things that aren't exactly on the menu.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Endless Options – The Loop, The Central West End, and Downtown Clayton all have an endless variety of restaurants that students love to go to. My personal favorite place is the The Central West End as the entire downtown area is really cute and they have great food, especially sushi.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Local, Healthy, and a High Variety – Any school's food, regardless of quality, will get old because it is offered according to a repetitive schedule.
That being said, it takes a long time to get tired of Wash U's food.  The three campus cafeterias have fried food, stir fry, pizza, salads, indian food, kosher food, SUSHI, and homestyle food.  There is also an exceptionally good fancy restaurant on campus, a subway, and many cafes.  I am very impressed with Wash U's food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Delicious but Unchanging – The food is all really good and there are tons of spots on campus to get food. However, the options never change, so it can get pretty tiring by the end of freshman year.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Better than most restaurants!! The Village is especially good!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Washington University prides itself in having one of the best quality meal options available to students. You buy food a la carte so students can eat at any time and purchase exactly the amount they want to eat. They have a stir fry station, grill, ethnic food, comfort food, pasta bar, etc. My personal favorite dining option is Holmes Lounge located on the academic part of campus that has fresh wraps that are amazing!!!!!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Delmar Loop – About three blocks north of Wash U's campus is a 2 mile stretch known as the Delmar Loop that is a great hot spot for restaurants, shopping, and entertainment.  Most of the restaurants are very reasonably priced and some even take student campus card points.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Solid Food, but Need More Options – The food around campus is very good during the first semester, but you get sick of it very quickly. Good options in the DUC, South 40, and of course Subway. I would recommend buying a small meal plan and adding points as you go.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Options – There are plenty of dining options on campus. Most of the dining halls offer a quality product and the food never gets repetitive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Quality – The food here is above and beyond.  Incomparable to any other college.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You really can't complain about food here. Dining halls are open really late and the food is unreal for a college.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Many Off-Campus Options – If you get tired of BD or the DUC, there a variety of restaurants nearby.  Kayak's is a popular choice near the engineering and art schools.  North of campus is the Loop that has various eateries such as Pi Pizzeria, Froyo, St. Louis Bread Co., Fitz's, Blueberry Hill, etc.  Many of these restaurants mentioned take campus card, and some even offer slight discounts for WashU students (ex. Ben and Jerry's).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Ursa's for the Win – I love the food here!  There is always a new option to try, but I have no problem eating the same thing every day.  Go to Ursa's, for sure.  Get the brownie sundae or a crepe, and also check out Holme's Lounge; great sandwiches.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Is Fantastic – The numerous dining venues and food options on campus is one of WashU's biggest draws.  You can find delicious Italian, Asian, deli, American, etc. food all around campus whether it be at the DUC, Bears Den, Holmes lounge, or one of the many cafes.  Considering it is college, the food quality is superb.  I can almost guarantee that if you ask any of your friends at another university, they would not be able to tell you they can find sushi or even a steak for dinner.  Also check out Ibby's, WashU's on campus restaurant, that serves the most high-quality, superb food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Jack Stack BBQ – In my opinion, the best bbq in the city! Affordable, excellent customer service, and delicious food. Relaxing, semi-formal atmosphere.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Varied and Quality – The university is situated next to the Delmar Loop, which has been named one of the best streets in America (although how they determined that is beyond me).  This lets students choose from a huge selection of restaurants.  For those whose tastes are a bit classier, the Central West End is only a quick train ride away, and boasts numerous very nice sit-down restaurants.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Excellent Dining – If you want diversity in food, you can definitely get it. There are lots of eating venues all over campus. I wish they would have more fresh food for dinner, but it's still easy to eat healthy.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food here is delicious; people actually miss food from here when they go home.  There are lots of different places to eat with different types of food (like the DUC) and there is food available from many international locations.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Perfect Atmosphere for College Students – A stone's throw away from campus is the U-City Loop, which has tons of casual dining restaurants, from national chains such as Chipotle to unique ethnic spots, like Ranoush, and a great St. Louis frozen yogurt shop called FroYo. In addition, the Clayton is quite upscale, so there are tons of nicer restaurants for a different dining experience.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Bear's Den – The new Bear's den is amazing. They've got a wide variety of foods ranging from the grill to pasta to mexican to stir fry. Prices are a bit high though. The servers/cashiers are very nice people as well.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: you'll find it. there are many restaurants near campus, including obama's allegedly favorite pizza place (pi pizza) just 10 minutes walking distance from campus. The loop is full of different cuisine to choose from (ranging from american to thai to japanese to chinese) and if you have a car, more options such as indian mexican korean etc are available. take the bus to brentwood (rides are free) for organic shops or department store food courts. the cheesecake factory (they sell tons more than just dessert) is a good bet in the area.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Best I've Seen at Any College – The new Bears Den is amazing with plenty of options: pizza, burgers, wraps, stir fry, pasta, salads, indian food, mexican food, sushi, etc. I don't see how I'm going to get bored of this
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a street called the loop right next to the campus and it has everything. Coffee shops Thai food, Froyo, Ice Cream, and Famous Pi Pizza.  It is a great place to hang out and the cost is totally acceptable
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We have fantastic food. You can get lobster tail, NY strip steak, fantastic wraps, great pizza, smoothies, gelato (italian ice-cream), and brownie sunday's all over campus. I miss the food when I'm home.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great Variety and Good Food – Even though Wash U's on campus food is gourmet, off-campus food is also great. You can get Sushi, Indian, Thai, Pizza, Chinese, Burgers, and much more (including Ethiopian!) within a short walk from campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Excellent Food, Many Halls – Freshman year life will revolve around the South 40 house.  As you get older you realize the amount of options that are available for the students
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: We have so much variety with our food on campus -- and most of it is really delicious.  There are plenty of healthy options along with more than enough ways to indulge!  Also, the food service staff are fantastic.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great Ethnic Food on the Loop! Right behind Washington University's campus there is a commercial street filled with both sit-down and fast food restaurants. It has the best ethnic food in St. Louis with affordable prices!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Excellent variety, quality, and availability.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food Is Great! I'm a vegetarian, and I've never had problems with finding options or variety in food. There's something for everyone and every kind of diet -- including vegan and kosher. The options can sometimes get repetitive, but it's awesome quality, and there are a lot of healthy options available to help avoid the freshmen 15.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Variety but Distant – Lots of different restaurants in the surrounding areas but nearly non-existent public and student transportation require students have a car.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Amazing and Sourced Responsibly – WashU has extremely green dining practices. The food could not taste better and much of it is sourced locally and with cruelty free/ fair trade practices.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great Restaurants All Around – There are tons of great restaurants all over. The Hill, the Central West End, and Clayton all have really nice places to eat when your parents are in town, but they also have more causal restaurants to go to with friends. You can find delicious food for a good price all over the city.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The loop has a lot of different types of restaurants from thai to japanese to chinese to sandwiches. There are a lot of very cheap places like Subway and Qdoba and some very expensive places like the Melting Pot and everything in between. Restaurants often offer discounts or coupons to students. Check out Pi-excellent pizza with moderate prices, a favorite of Obama.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Is Great – food is all made to order so it is always fresh, but sometimes the lines are really long. There are multiple places to eat around campus that all have different options. I sometimes wish there were more healthy choices at more places and less grilled/fried options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Mostly Great, Some Bad – some areas around campus are really nice, like the Loop and Central West End...but St Louis has its dangerous areas that i usually avoid
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Depends on Where You Eat – this year has been bad on the south 40- huge cuts in vegetarian options and variety, and the quality had declined a lot in the vegetables and salad bar. on main campus the food is excellent and ethnically diverse
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are very spacious. Every dorm has a kitchen, laundry room, computer room, and some other fun things like ping pong.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The modern dorms feel like a hotel. They are unbelievably nice. The traditional dorms are nice too and still significantly better than the dorms at other schools.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: If you live in a modern dorm, you are living the dream! Our worst dorms, or the traditional dorms, are still far better than dorms at most colleges, but they are still pretty average. The school has a high ranking for dorms because of the moderns, but don't expect that much if you're in a traditional.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Some dorms are better than others, but all are at least decent.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: On the South 40 where the underclassman live it depends on what style you want.  Traditional 6 person apartments let you get to know the 6 people you live with really well mostly because there is a large common room in the suite.  The floor style for the newer buildings lets you get to know a lot of people only a little bit.  The traditionals are older but are among the best options and I think the social atmosphere was great.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: If you get good housing, its AMAZING. Even if you don't the dorms are still better than a lot of housing at other schools.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms are beautiful, the South 40 is unbelievably awesome for freshmen and sophomores as far as an undergraduate living space
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Overall, I am pleased with the quality of the dorms, but I wouldn't say its worth the headache. It's A LOT cheaper to get an apartment in STL and you don't have to deal with annoying party rules.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you're black cisgender heterosexual female, it's fine. I have no complaints. It's a little dry from time to time but that's life.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing department may be very strict on what they fine you for, but the rooms themselves are great and the RAs and WUSAs are very nice in my experience.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You can't go wrong freshmen year-- either modern dorms will give you a nicer place to live with a few close suitemates/roommates or the traditional dorms will give you communal bathrooms and an adequate living space (less comfortable compared to the moderns, but still nicer than most other schools' residences) but a much closer floor and therefore more friends right away. The maintenance staff is terrific and speedy so there are never any big problems with WashU housing, on or off campus, that do not get fixed within a day or two. Staff is friendly and there are options to fit everyone. All housing is expensive as is the nature of WashU.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: If I had one different RA the housing would be amazing
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Amazing housing, and as long as you get anywhere in your top three to five choices you'll be taken care of really nicely.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The main problem with housing is that it is very expensive. Otherwise, they have the best of both worlds; there are modern and traditional dorms. I have not talked to a freshman who did not get their pick for modern vs. traditional dorms. The freshman and sophomores -- most sophomores live on campus -- live on the South Forty. Very few sophomores along with all the upperclassmen who live on campus live in the Village. The South Forty has memory foam beds and a great cafeteria.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The South 40 is a great place to live as a Freshman or a Sophomore. The community is great and the dorms are unbelievably big, private, and updated. The housing process gets a lot more difficult after sophomore year. There are fewer options on campus and lottery numbers play a huge role on whether you can even get decent campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in a modern triple, and I love my room. It's very spacious. In addition, the random selection process of choosing roommates was a positive experience for me. I really like my roommates, as we live well together.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living in a modern triple is the best choice I could've made. It's one of the cheapest options and it makes socializing easier because there are always people around.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: They keep improving it. It's expensive though.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The room I have is a modern double. The way we have it set it up it is so spacious. The bathrooms never get too bad. My roommate and I share our bathroom with our two suitemates and housekeeping cleans it twice a week. Our only major responsibility in terms of the bathroom is taking out the trash. Outside of the room there are a lot of places to study. Each floor has two study rooms and a common room with a kitchenette. On the first floor, there's a laundry room, a multipurpose room, a full kitchen, a seminar room, and two practice rooms with pianos.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: WashU guarantees housing whether it be off or on campus for all four years if students choose to partake. Huge variety of what type of off campus housing you want. You can have it be the nicest apartment in the world or just a typical one depending on your price range.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: All housing options have incredible rooms. Whether it be suite style, or a typical college dorm layout, you will find an incredible living situation with regard to the quality of living space as well as the social atmosphere and floor community.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing is amazing. Residential Life really focuses on providing comfortable living arrangements for all students.  It is also nice because they put all of the underclassmen in the same area, so you are alway surrounded by people that are your own age.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing is great, convenient, easy to get food and to get to class.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I've only stayed in one place that was off campus, and that was during the summer. So I'm not sure how relevant my experience is. The place I stayed at had really cheap rent ($380 per month), but it was quite dirty. It was in a safe neighborhood though, and a ten minute walk from the Brookings end of campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is amazing. Freshman dorms all have Tempurpedic mattresses, and rooms are a decent size. WashU really tries to match roommates up, and if all else fails you'll at least make friends with people you otherwise would never have even spoken to. You're guaranteed 4 years of housing, and as someone who's lived on campus every year, the process is fairly easy. Maintenance requests are promptly answered, and I've never had problems with RA's. Overall, I'd rate WashU housing as really great.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The modern dorms are like castles (ex. Koenig lobby); the traditional dorms are probably average at other schools. Expensive, and the lottery can really screw people over. But if you get lucky, you're golden. Traditionals do have better communities than moderns, but regardless, I'm moving from a traditional to a modern next year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Centrally located and easy access to the city and school.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Campus life is mediocre. Not much social scene.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is overall excellent, the best in the country many people say. However the residential college system doesn't make a ton of sense and isn't used for anything except the housing lottery, and with reslife attempting to push more sophomores into traditionally junior housing it's those who currently live in the cheaper options and cannot afford/do not want to pay for the most expensive housing that are being screwed. The school does not want to have traditional dorms available anymore despite the small but strong contingent who enjoys them their cheaper pricetag and high satisfaction rates every year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: They help give you one on one help, making sure you keep up the pace in class, help you move to the next level so you will be successful. Your last school year you will have an internship, automatically get hired on after you graduate. They will help you find a job in your career path, that's what makes them special.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: best dorms in the country
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's nice because the University owns off-campus apartments for upper classmen, and these are relatively close to the school, so it's pretty stress free when it comes to finding a place to live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms here are wonderful; they are spacious, with nice carpeting and temper-pedic mattresses. They are very clean. Most dorms have personal bathrooms shared among 4-6 others, and the school provides cleaning staff to clean the showers, sink, and bathroom stall. The dorms are pretty expensive, but they are luxurious compared to many other universities.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are a bit expensive, but it i well worth every penny. From the tempurpedic mattresses to the maids that clean your bathrooms once a week, it is almost like living in a hotel filled with your closest friends.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: There are multiple places to live that are close to campus, but it will be hard to let go of all the amenities that the South 40 has to offer
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: On campus housing is so great so most only live off campus senior year! Even then, housing is easy to find and pretty close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: You cannot find better dorms anywhere else.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Best dorms I have ever seen. The fact that all beds in student housing are tempurpedic mattresses speaks to the quality.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Probably the best on-campus housing of any major university in the country.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing is not far from main campus. Prices range from affordable to expensive depending on quality
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Washu has some very nice apartments off campus that are within walking distance and provide greater access to the city and more freedom from administration
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The school owns many apartments off campus and works hand in hand with landlords around the school. They also work with the city to try and get public transportation from those apartments to the school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I'm honestly not really sure about the off-campus housing...but I hear it's decent.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus can be really nice, depending on where you live. If you are on the South 40, life is pretty nice. The dorms are decently spacious and there is a nice field and volleyball court and basketball court there too. Some of the traditional dorms are kind of run down, but the moderns are really nice. The worst dorm hands down is Rubleman House (we call it Ruby). The best for freshmen is Umrath House, and the best for sophomores and upperclassmen who still live on the 40 is South Forty House (SoFoHo). Ironically, they are all a par of the same residential college (groupings of houses, usually with their own colors and mascots and consist usually of a freshman and sophomore building). Most all of the housing is kind of expensive though.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A lot of housing near campus and social spots such as University City and Central West End. Not bad cost considering the locations.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorm room as big as my house.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: If you get a roommate off campus housing can be an excellent way to save money. If you are like me and are willing to pay a little more to get a place on your own to enjoy the privacy and freedom of living alone.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Much of the off-campus housing is still owned by the university so it is easy to obtain under the housing lottery. As well, it is very protected by campus police and blue-lights or campus to home rides are available to all off-campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are traditional (older buildings) and modern (newer buildings). The modern buildings could not be more wonderful, but the older buildings have some space, aesthetic, and air conditioning issues. They are working to replace all the traditional buildings with modern ones in the coming years. Regardless of age of building, all campus housing has computer and printing labs, community kitchens, very supportive cleaning and maintenance staff/schedules, and strong community spirit.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Many people seek off-campus housing because of the high cost of on-campus housing.  Those who've gotten it didn't seem to have any trouble and there are a number of available locations that are near campus (many are/can be closer to your classes the the on-campus dorms haha)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great dorms, kind of pricey
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You can get all of the help you need through the school and it's all very reasonably priced.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are AMAZING. my bed here is more comfortable than my bed at home
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: So far i have not been able to find a decent loft for off-campus stay.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: From what I have heard so far, the on-campus housing options are some the best in the whole country and some websites rate them at top 3.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Housing is great because everything is clean! They have people come and clean the bathrooms in certain dorms!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is great! St. Louis is also great!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great Housing!! Love my dorm!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing constantly gets ranked among the best in the country.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Amazing. Tons of options! Whatever suits you.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Top notch. I have some friends who live off campus and they say they love it!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: WUSTL is known for its top housing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing is cheaper depending on where you go.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: From what I've heard, it is phenomenal.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: One of the biggest reasons WashU attracted me was not only the amazing academics but the housing options. Supposedly the dorms are the best in the country and are extremely clean and if you ask a WashU student they will surely attest to this.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I really enjoy campus life. Very comfortable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Only have lived on campus so really can't answer
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It is much more affordable than on-campus housing, so I would recommend moving out sophomore or junior year.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Housing is great, but costly. Most students move off-campus in their third-year (when they get shafted by the lottery system), but it's no big deal as by that time you've found a solid friend-group. But it may make you feel nostalgic about your first two, very expensive, years on campus because the dorms are so nice and the off-campus options...aren't as nice.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Finding off-campus housing is relatively easy. The school has a relationship with an off-campus housing company that is pretty bureaucratic, but makes finding apartments relatively easy so long as you plan in advance. It's significantly cheaper than living on campus, but you do miss the convenience of knocking on a random door in the dorm hallways and making a new friend.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I think the facilities could be better, but they have just put in new apartments.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: We have wonderful campus housing in the modern dorms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The South 40 looks like a Disney Resort.  Wash U has spent the last couple of years tearing down the traditional dorms to construct more modern dormitories.  The atmosphere is welcoming, especially for freshman with the "freshman floors."
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: As a freshman I've only been exposed to one type of dorm, and in my case, it's a traditional dorm. I live in a double. The first few weeks were tough to adjust as the small room, scratchy carpet, ugly yellow walls, "riot-proof" labyrinth hallways, communal bathrooms, and noisy floormmates were anything but home. That soon changed, and it's grown on me quite a bit. I've come to love my room and my floor mates, and my entire dorm basically, and i can't really imagine living life at Wash U any other way. The staff are friendly and keep the dorms clean, and any complaints are kept to a minimum as everyone is respectful. Since I live in a traditional, cost is fine. Everything I'd need or want is very close to the dorm.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms range from traditional hallway style dorms to modern suite style dorms. They both have their perks and their problems. Overall though, the community feel is everywhere on campus. There are computer labs and laundry rooms in all buildings and some places have kitchens.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The amenities are great, but again it is difficult for anyone on a budget to stay in the lavish on campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Living off campus is a great option for individuals who do not have the money to pay for the on-campus housing (which can be $14,000+ a year). The university does not help AT ALL in terms of moving off campus. They really want you to stay in the WashU bubble.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: variety of options and prices, university ensures good landlords.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are very nice, no problems at all.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are some really nice options through wash u and independently. I've been living in a non-wash u apt for the past year and I love it. It's very do-able and still very close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: So our dorms are ranked pretty high, and they are really nice and spacious. However, housing is expensive, and if you are unlucky, as an upperclassmen, you might wind up living back on the "40" (the first and second year dorms) if you have bad lottery numbers. In addition to this, one of the biggest problems with the housing system is that once you leave campus (move off-campus), you are ineligible to move back in campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms are clean and there are very comfortable mattresses.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It is beautiful comfortable and convenient to campus. There are lots of options including apartment style housing for upperclassmen (having a kitchen is amazing). It can be a little pricy, but it's definitely worth it.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing meets Wash U's already sterling housing reputation. The locations are not far from campus, they are kept in good condition, and they are often very spacious. Most off-campus housing is situated in relatively safe neighborhoods, but if not, the school offers a shuttle service that drives you back home at any hour of the night.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: WashU's worst dorms are better than most college's best dorms. From the balconies and tempur-pedic beds to the common rooms and room service, nobody really complains. Dorms are convenient, very close to campus, and dorms are grouped together by year to make socializing easy.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There is a lot of off-campus housing, usually just one street off campus, some even owned by the university. Off-campus housing is usually accessible and generally cheaper than on-campus housing. However, University City is not the safest of areas, and thus, there is a safety concern when considering late-nights spent on campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There is both Off-Campus Housing through Residential Life and not and both are nice and relatively cheap.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms are huge and new.  All freshmen live on the South 40 which is a residential community south of campus.  The overall atmosphere is excellent. Through floor activities and general proximity, I have become great friends with my floor as well as other people on the 40.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Some of the most amazing dorm rooms that you will ever see. They're gorgeous and most of them are modern so you will only share a bathroom with your 3 suitemates.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off campus housing through Quadrangle is a little more expensive than getting housing independently, and the company is relatively disorganized.  However, they have an emergency service that you can call at any time and someone will come to fix whatever you need that day.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I am renting a house that's within a stone's throw of campus.  It's also much cheaper than paying for university housing.  Great options are available, but a lot of people still choose to live in either fraternities, the village, or in washu off campus apartments. Because of that, students live between normal full-time residents and there aren't any total student streets.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Top Notch – As someone who toured almost 20 schools, I can honestly say WashU has some of the nicest, newest dorms in the country.  While the new applies to the modern dorms, the traditional dorms have a reputation for fostering a great community (modern do as well it's just something traditionals pride themselves in) so it's a win-win either way.  Sophomores have the luxury of suite-style housing either opting for a newer modern with four people per suite or a slightly older but balcony-included six-person living situation.  Between tempurpedic mattresses, spacious rooms, and the inclusive environment of the South 40, WashU students truly have it all when it comes to housing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Traditional Floors Can Adopt You – The dorms are EXTREMELY nice, almost like luxury hotels, well, at least the modern ones are - the traditional ones aren't as nice (kinda crappy). However, a lot of the people in modern dorms are kind of antisocial, and if you're not, then you might find a traditional floor to "adopt" you
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: off campus housing is great. wash u does a great job of helping students out and many times off campus housing is much less expensive than on campus
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorms Are Great!! The dorms are huge and have beautiful, wooden meeting rooms. Some of the best dorms in the country.
Housing.Author: College Student

Housing.Review: The South 40 – It is a very interesting atmosphere. Bear's Den is the central dining area and central social place. Lots of places to study throughout the South 40. Most groceries, school supplies can be found at stores on the South 40, but are more expensive than they should be.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Excellent Housing Options – Even WashU's worst dorms are nicer than the dorms at many colleges. WashU does a great job of making sure their students are well taken care of. The rooms, on average, are also very spacious, comfortable, and well furnished (some even come with tempurpedic matresses).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Gorgeous and Spacious – Even the freshman dorms are beautiful. All of the rooms are huge and some come with tempur-pedic mattresses and their own thermostats. Both the South 40 and the Village are great places to live.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Love Living on Campus – I LOVE living on campus.  This year (freshman year) I'm living in Danforth which is a modern dorm.
