The suite styles are great- 4 people to a bathroom, good size room and closet, and enough storage space.  I love the co-ed floors too; it makes it easy to make friends.  The dining hall is close to almost all dorms and has great food.  It's a bit expensive, but worth it to live on campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Not Very Safe – They do not provide a "how to"manual on where and where not to go: students have absolutely NO CLUE as to where the safe locations and non safe locations are in St. Louis off campus
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: You can live in the most amazing housing possible with tempurpedic mattresses and your own bathroom, but there are still a couple of older buildings that need to be torn down.  But the majority of the housing is wonderful and still clean and well-kept.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms Like Palaces – Dorms are wonderful. Rooms are huge, for both modern and traditional housing. Most rooms have temperapeutic mattresses. Modern suites have four people sharing a bathroom, and housekeeping twice a week for the bathroom. Each floor has a kitchen, and each dorm has a laundry room and a computer lab. Substance-free housing available. Costly.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Leasing is really inexpensive in St. Louis, but the apartments close to campus are older and have really high utility bills.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I have yet to see any other school's dorms that compare to ours.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Traditional and Modern. Both Great Choices – The dorms are really nice compared to most schools, and the rooms are pretty big. If you prefer a traditional dorm, you get temperpedic mattresses, and those dorms tend to have more parties. The modern dorms are great too, of course, because you can live with three of your good friends and you have your own private bathroom. I would recommend traditional for your first year because it's easier to meet people, and then you can live in a modern the next year.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Available and usually well priced. Off campus housing also provided by the university at a reasonable rate.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms Are Like Ski-Lodges – Tempur-pedic style mattresses, huge flat-screen TVs, leather couches, huge rooms and common areas. It doesn't get better than this.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Close to Campus and Nice – There are great apartments very close to campus. Many Juniors and Seniors live there and really have a close-knit group of Wash U students off campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on Campus – The dorms are great and housekeeping thoroughly cleans your bathroom at least twice a week. Maintenance is prompt and very skilled. The laundry system is a bit annoying as you have to pay quite a bit for the washer and dryer...it amounts to about 2 dollars each time. Also, you have to dry your things in two cycles because the dryer isn't powerful enough. You can fit into any social group you want really, we have everything.  The sports scene isn't too lively though because our school is DIII.  It's a private school so it is crazily expensive, unless you get near a full ride I wouldn't go here over a state school.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Non-Washu Housing – I took moving off campus to mean that I was an adult. The responsibilities that come with the real world suck a bit, but it's better for me to learn this now rather than later. Non-WashU Off Campus bonuses:
-No RAs
-After no searching you can find a place for much (MUCH) less than any WashU housing, and with a little more searching you can find relatively inexpensive apartments.
-Can lease over the summer, meaning that you won't have to move your stuff a million more times from place to place. My apartment is home...my dorm was definitely not. Dorms made me feel like a hobo.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms Are Like Palaces – Dorm rooms are huge and modern... twice the size of a normal dorm room.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review:
Apartments, Hit or Miss – pros: price, occasionally location, freedom, kitchen, space
cons: safety, occasionally location, negligent landlords
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Dorms are nice – The dorms are very nice. The modern ones in the 40 have fairly large (for a dorm) sized rooms and one bathroom for 4. The dorms in the Village (upperclassmen) are much nicer, one bathroom for 2, some have double beds and kitchens.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: All the Dorms Are Nice – I am not a huge fan of traditional style dorms but a lot of freshmen are and they are great for floor bonding. I personally think the modern dorms are beautiful no matter what grade you are in.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Lots of Apartments – Lots of apartments around campus for students. They are pretty reasonably price, though they have had some safety issues in the past
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I chose to live off-campus my senior year much to the dismay of my parents.  However, I am closer to the library than I ever was in my three years on campus.  I live on a street called Kingsbury, where pretty much must of the more social Greek life members live.  We are so close to the Loop that in the mornings I can grab coffee at Panera and at night I can walk to Blue Hill to get a beer. My parents are now on board.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I have honestly never seen cleaner, more spacious, or better looking dorms on any other campus.  Students, whether upper classmen or freshman are not piled on top of one another, but instead have enough room to feel comfortable and as if they have their own space.  The bathroom situation is also the best that I have seen.  In the modern dorms, students may be 2-4 for a bathroom, and even in the older dorms, the hall bathrooms are clean and uni-sex.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing is great! Wash U spoils most underclassmen with housing. The modern dorms are very, very nice, and all of the traditional dorms receive tempurpedic mattresses as a consolation for not being in modern. Traditionals are still very nice though too. The halls are big enough in all of the dorms to have a fun, social atmosphere.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off Campus Living – Apartments are in a variety of places but living off campus through the school is more expensive than finding a place on your own.  Greenway and U. Drive apartments are incredibly nice though and the location near delmar but not far from school is nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior
